I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
loan and (ii) proposed administration of a grant to be provided by the Government of Australia, 
both to the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam for the Central Mekong Delta Region Connectivity 
Project.1 
 
2.  The project will improve connectivity in the Mekong Delta Region and provide efficient 
access from Ho Chi Minh City to the Southern Coastal Region through construction of a section 
of  the  Second  Southern  Highway  (SSH)  comprising  two  cable-stayed  bridges  across  the 
Mekong River, one at Cao Lanh and the other at Vam Cong, and associated roads. 
 
3.  The  project  is  located  on  the  boundaries  of  An  Giang,  Can  Tho,  and  Dong  Thap 
provinces to the west of the Mekong Delta Region. The bridges will be constructed to six-lane 
carriageway standard, with two lanes initially reserved for motorcycle traffic. The interconnecting 
road will be constructed to four-lane standard, to be widened to six-lane standard in the future. 
The Asian Development Bank (ADB) and the Government of Australia are proposed to finance 
the Cao Lanh bridge and the interconnecting road, and the Government of Korea to provide 
parallel financing for the Vam Cong bridge and its associated road works.2 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
A.  Rationale 
4.  Viet Nam has a rapidly growing export-led economy; it is the world’s second largest rice 
exporter. The economy of the Mekong Delta, a key economic region, relies mainly on agro-
industry and other light industries. The Mekong Delta produces more than 60% of Viet Nam’s 
agricultural and fishery outputs, and is the country’s third largest producer of light industrial 
goods. Consequently, rapidly growing motorization with an inefficient transport network will soon 
lead to severe congestion of the sole arterial link—National Highway 1A—a four-lane single 
carriageway road that cannot be widened due to dense inhabitation. Severe congestion could 
negatively affect domestic food distribution as well as Viet Nam’s exports, and would certainly 
increase the cost of food and exports. To sustain economic development of this region, the 
government plans to construct a parallel arterial link from Ho Chi Minh City to the Mekong Delta 
and southern coastal provinces. 
 
5.  The government’s expressway development plan identifies the SSH as a key artery for 
development of the Mekong Delta.3 The SSH connects Ho Chi Minh City through the Mekong 
Delta to the southern coastal region and serves as an alternative to National Highway 1A. It also 
provides  access  to  the  region’s  western  provinces,  and  connects  to  the  Greater  Mekong 
Subregion  Southern  Coastal  Corridor  in  An  Giang  province,  which  connects  to  highway 
networks in Cambodia and Thailand. The project will help diversify and develop the region’s 
economy  into  the  western  provinces.  The  western  provinces  are  predominantly  rural  and 
relatively poor. This is primarily due to poor connectivity, which has resulted in the region’s 
industries locating and concentrating in the southeastern provinces along National Highway 1A.

6.  The two-lane SSH is currently constrained by ferry crossings at Cao Lanh and Vam 
Cong, which are slow and cause traffic delays. The government plans to remove the bottlenecks 
caused by these ferries and, more generally, improve connectivity in the Mekong Delta by 
constructing a section of the SSH between Cao Lanh (on the northern bank of the Tien branch 
of the Mekong River) and Long Xuyen (on the southern bank of the Hau branch).  
 
7.  ADB is assisting the government to realize its transport investment program, increase 
transport efficiency, and reduce transport costs. ADB’s strategy for Viet Nam focuses on (i) 
alignment with the priorities of the government’s Socio-Economic Development Plan, 2011–
2015 as they intersect with ADB’s Strategy 2020, (ii) investments that offer value-addition and 
innovative solutions, (iii) support for the government's commitment to economic restructuring 
and related reforms, and (iv) strategic partnerships with development partners to implement 
commitments under the Paris Declaration.4 The government identifies the project as a high 
priority and included it in its 5-year plan.  The governments of Australia and the Republic of 
Korea, in support of their bilateral partnerships, have committed to provide financial support; for 
both development partners, this is the largest amount provided for a single project in Viet Nam. 
 
8.  The  project  is  expected  to  bring  inclusive  development  to  areas  that  are  poorly 
connected to major population centers, improve access to basic social and health services, 
increase national food security by stimulating the local agro-industry and boosting exports, 
facilitate private sector investment, and extend regional connectivity to neighboring Cambodia 
and the Greater Mekong Subregion, as well as to Viet Nam’s major inland ports in the Mekong 
Delta. An estimated 170,000 road users will benefit daily from the project; the 5 million residents 
of An Giang, Can Tho, and Dong Thap provinces will benefit from improved living standards.  
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The expected impact is improved and sustainable transport connectivity contributing to 
inclusive development in the Central Mekong Delta Region. The expected outcome is improved 
road transport access and travel time across and within the Central Mekong Delta Region.  
 
C.  Outputs 
10.  The project will build a section of the SSH, including two cable-stayed bridges with a 
combined length of about 5 kilometers (km) and associated access and interconnecting roads 
with a total length of about 26 km, and provide systems for bridge health monitoring, traffic 
management, and emergency response. The project comprises component 1, Cao Lanh bridge 
(2.0 km) and approach roads (5.8 km); component 2, interconnecting road (15.7 km); and 
component 3, Vam Cong bridge (3.0 km) and approach roads (4.5 km) to be financed by the 
Export–Import Bank of Korea (KEXIM).5 This output will be achieved through construction, 
associated project management, and safeguard implementation and monitoring activities.6 
 
D.  Investment and Financing Plans

resources to help finance the project.7 The loan will have a 31-year term, including a grace 
period  of  6  years  (straight-line  repayment  method),  an  annual  interest  rate  determined  in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  London  interbank  offered  rate  (LIBOR)-based  lending  facility,  a 
commitment charge of 0.15% per year on the undisbursed loan amount (the interest and other 
charges during construction to be capitalized in the loan), and such other terms and conditions 
set forth in the draft loan agreement. The average loan maturity is 18.75 years, and the maturity

resettlement expenses through retroactive financing, as well as part of the taxes. The eligibility 
of these items for ADB financing was determined through a due diligence assessment, which 
focused on (i) the expected productive nature of land to be acquired, (ii) suitability of land 
market conditions, (iii) adequacy of administrative arrangements to ensure transparent and 
efficient transfer of funds, (iv) risk profile of the transaction, (v) soundness of the monitoring and 
evaluation  arrangements,  and  (vi)  the  country  partnership  strategy  recommendation  for 
financing  taxes  that  apply  to  ADB-financed  expenditures.  Based  on  the  results  of  the 
assessments, ADB concluded that all requirements had been met.8

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The Ministry of Transport (MOT) will be the executing agency. Cuu Long Corporation for 
Investment, Development and Project Management of Infrastructure (Cuu Long CIPM), under 
MOT, will be the implementing agency and will be responsible for the direct supervision and 
day-to-day project implementation. The provincial peoples committees in Dong Thap province 
and Can Tho city and their respective centers for land fund development will implement the 
project’s resettlement plans.  
 
16.  A project coordinating committee (PCC) will provide overall direction and management. 
It will be responsible for ensuring coordination across all aspects of project implementation; 
resolving technical and contractual issues as they arise; and monitoring implementation of the 
project’s safeguard programs, in particular programs for addressing involuntary resettlement 
and  environmental  impact  mitigation.  The  PCC  will  meet  semiannually  during  project 
implementation, when possible coinciding with the cofinanciers’ joint review missions. 
 
17.  The MOT vice-minister responsible for the project will chair the PCC. PCC members will 
include representatives of the cofinanciers, the provinces within the project area, and relevant 
central  government  ministries  and  agencies.  The  Cuu  Long  CIPM  will  act  as  the  PCC 
secretariat in coordination with relevant MOT departments. The vice chairs of the respective 
provincial peoples committees will chair the provincial coordination meetings to implement the 
project’s social programs.  
 
18.  Associated  with  the  project,  ADB  approved  a  detailed  design  and  implementation 
support technical assistance (DDIS-TA), fully financed by the Government of Australia.10 This

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
A.  Technical  
23.  The project is located within the heart of the Mekong Delta—a region characterized by 
an  extensive  inland  waterway  network  that  serves  irrigation,  international  navigation, 
transportation, and many other domestic purposes. The waterway network connects with the 
Mekong River, which at the project site exists as two separate branches, the Hau and the Tien.

7 
A road constructed through this area requires multiple bridges to cross the two main branches 
of the Mekong River and many smaller canals and river channels. 
 
24.  For  the  two  main  river  crossings,  the  proposed  cable-stayed  bridge  structures  are 
appropriate  and  dictated  mainly  by  the  need  for  large  horizontal  and  vertical  navigation 
clearance. The bridges are within the scale of similar structures, including the My Thuan and Can 
Tho  bridges  located  downstream  from  the  project  site,  and  will  be  constructed  to  six-lane 
configuration with one lane on each side reserved for motorcycle use. The project includes  
26 small to medium-sized bridges, 6 of which provide for navigational requirements. For the 
interconnecting road and smaller bridges, the selected alignment and cross-section standards are 
appropriate for the intended traffic use and forecast traffic volume, and will be constructed to four-
lane configuration with a directional separation median. The road sections are access controlled, 
which  provides  for  safe  crossing,  merging,  and  diverging  traffic  movements.  Passage  for 
pedestrians, nonmotorized traffic, and agricultural equipment is provided by dedicated crossings 
under the bridges, at an average of one crossing per kilometer. The detailed designs address all 
technical and design aspects, and an independent proof-check certificate was issued. A road 
safety audit has also been undertaken and incorporated in the project’s detailed designs.13 
 
25.  The Mekong Delta is identified as one of the world’s most vulnerable regions to climate 
change. Predicted changes to the climate of the delta area, and more generally to the Mekong 
River catchment upstream of the delta, could increase both the magnitude and frequency of 
floods and storms and induce greater seasonal variability in weather patterns. Taken together, 
these risks potentially reduce the intended design life of large infrastructure works. The project’s 
technical designs include climate change adaptation measures to mitigate these risks. The 
adaptation features include increased height for road embankments and larger clearance for 
bridges based on recommendations of the government’s Ministry of Natural Resources and 
Environment, supported by studies conducted by the design consultants and parallel regional 
technical assistance commissioned by ADB.14 
 
B.  Economic and Financial 
26.  The project is economically viable with an economic internal rate of return of 17%. The 
sensitivity analysis shows that the project is resilient to likely variations in critical parameters 
and remains economically viable with an economic internal rate of return of 12.7% when all 
sensitivity parameters are concurrently set to their lowest values. The risk analysis shows less 
than a 1% risk that the project’s economic internal rate of return will fall below ADB's cutoff rate 
for economic viability of 12%.15 
  
27.  The project will not generate revenue. Financial analysis assessed the project owner’s 
financial capacity to sustainably maintain the project. Until 2013, road maintenance funding was 
allocated from the national budget and increased from D1,537 billion to D4,377 billion during 
2007–2013 for the entire national road network (18,000 km) in line with the prevailing national 
inflation rates. This  met  about  50%  of  the  required  road maintenance  needs,  and  budget 
planning and allocation normally followed set timelines and procedures without many delays. In 
2013,  the  government,  as  part  of  overall  road  subsector  reform  and  transition  to  a  more 
sustainable maintenance program, introduced a road fund, financed from a combination of 
vehicle registration fees and budgetary allocations. Specific to this project, the government’s 
                                                
13 Road Safety Audit Report (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
14 ADB. 2012. Draft Final Report. Central Mekong Delta Region Connectivity Project: Rapid Climate Change Threat 
and Vulnerability Assessment. Manila (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).  
15 Economic and Financial Analyses (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

8 
policies and regulations for operation and maintenance (O&M) of large and complex transport 
infrastructure require that O&M budgets be prioritized and allocated based on the performance-
based plans developed specifically for such projects. The DDIS-TA will prepare an O&M plan 
and manuals for the project. The government has provided assurances that an O&M plan will be 
developed, implemented, and financed to ensure long-term sustainability of the project facilities. 
 
C.  Governance 
28.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the government. The specific policy requirements and necessary measures are described in 
the project administration manual (footnote 12). The findings of the financial and procurement 
capacity assessment of the implementing agency indicate that Cuu Long CIPM (i) employs 115 
staff  with  seven  project  management  divisions;  (ii)  has  sufficient  financial  administration  and 
procurement capacity to efficiently manage the project; and (iii) has successfully implemented 
major development partner-funded projects, including the My Thuan cable-stayed bridge financed 
by the Government of Australia and the Can Tho cable-stayed bridge funded by the Government of 
Japan,  and  is  currently  implementing  the  ADB-financed  Southern  Coastal  Corridor  Project 
cofinanced  by  the  governments  of  Australia  and  the  Republic  of  Korea.  The  financial  and 
procurement management assessments do not identify any major outstanding risks or issues.16 
 
D.  Poverty and Social 
29.  A social impact assessment prepared for the project identifies the following as potentially 
significant adverse project impacts: (i) land acquisition and resettlement, (ii) changed livelihoods 
associated with disruption of ferry traffic and changed traffic flow, (iii) access to and mobility on 
local roads once the highway and bridges are constructed, (iv) road safety, and (v) risk of 
HIV/AIDS  and  human  trafficking.  The  assessment  also  highlights  that  women  are  more 
vulnerable to hardship due to the loss of economic and social base caused by land acquisition, 
relocation, and livelihood impacts. 
 
30.  Based on the social impact assessment, a social action plan (SAP) was prepared to 
ensure that the project’s social benefits are maximized and its adverse impacts are mitigated, if 
they cannot be avoided. It incorporates gender inclusive interventions related to the prevention 
of HIV/AIDS and human trafficking. The SAP is estimated to cost $1.2 million; it is financed 
outside of the project scope under the DDIS-TA. In addition, a subproject financed by the 
Gender  and  Development  Cooperation  Fund  is  supporting  the  economic  empowerment  of 
women residing near the project area, as well as reducing their vulnerability and exposure to 
risks as a result of increased physical connectivity.17 Gender issues are integrated into the 
resettlement  plan,  including  actions  to  ensure  that  all  compensation  payments  and  cash 
assistance are provided jointly in the name of husband and wife. In addition, contractors will be 
encouraged to employ women and provide equal pay for equal work. Under the DDIS-TA, 
female project implementation personnel of Cuu Long CIPM will undergo training programs 
relevant to the project activities. Since most gender-specific actions are undertaken outside the 
project scope, for gender classification the project is categorized as having no gender element. 
 
                                                
16 Financial Management Assessment and Procurement Capacity Assessment (accessible from the list of linked 
document in Appendix 2).   
17 ADB. 2007. Promoting Gender Equality and Women’s Empowerment. Manila.

9 
E.  Safeguards 
31.  In  compliance  with  ADB’s  SPS,  the  project  is  categorized  as  A  for  involuntary 
resettlement and environment. As the project is not expected to affect any ethnic minorities, it is 
categorized as C for indigenous peoples. 
 
32.  Resettlement plans for Can Tho city and Dong Thap province, based on ADB’s SPS, 
were prepared under the DDIS-TA, and posted on ADB’s website on 9 April 2013. The project 
will require a total land area of 255 hectares. Land acquisition will affect 7,139 people (1,555 
households). About 1,000 of these households will lose productive land and 558 households will 
require relocation.18 A grievance redress mechanism to address resettlement-related complaints 
was established under the people’s committees of the project provinces. The income restoration 
programs, which are part of the project’s resettlement plans, will be funded under the DDIS-TA 
and will be implemented over 2 years during 2013–2014. 
 
33.  A draft environmental impact assessment and environment management plan, based on 
ADB’s SPS, were prepared under the DDIS-TA, and posted on ADB’s website on 22 January 
2013. The project alignment will traverse mostly agricultural land and the fringes of urban areas. 
There is little natural landscape along the alignment. No forests, conservation areas, or reserves 
are in the vicinity of the project. The air quality data along two existing roads close to the project 
alignment show an increasing trend of particulate concentration due to the increasing number of 
vehicles  and  motorcycles  using  the  ferries  and  vehicles  idling  during  ferry  loading  and 
unloading.  The  environmental  management  plan  includes  detailed  environmental  mitigation 
measures and corresponding monitoring requirements to avoid or minimize adverse impacts 
during  various  project  phases.  The  government  has  assured  ADB  that  consultations  with 
affected  persons  will  continue  during  project  operation  to  ensure  that  actual  impacts  are 
adequately addressed. The DDIS-TA includes an environmental awareness raising and training 
program to improve the environmental management capacity of Cuu Long CIPM. 
 
34.  Civil society, including project-affected people, and various government agencies from 
the project provinces were consulted during 2009–2012. The project contractors will develop a 
grievance redress mechanism for environmental management prior to commencement of civil 
works. In addition, under the DDIS-TA, international external resettlement and environmental 
monitoring  consultants  will  be  engaged  to  verify  the  activities  related  to  resettlement  and 
environment safeguard compliance. The external monitoring will be done on an annual basis for 
environment and on a semiannual basis for resettlement. 
 
F.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
35.  A risk assessment and risk management plan was prepared.19 The major risks associated 
with the project, when mitigated, are low and  include (i) project road and bridges not built, 
maintained, and operated to the specified standards; (ii) major traffic accidents and ship collision 
with the bridges; (iii) impact of climate change; (iv) procurement and corruption; (v) environmental, 
social, and resettlement issues; and (vi) unforeseen construction delays. The risk of substandard 
construction quality is mitigated through design and procurement arrangements that require the 
designers and civil works contractors to meet strict qualifications. In addition, technical designs 
incorporate provisions for climate change adaptation, safety and emergency response systems, 
and have been proof-checked by an independent consultant. The government has provided an 
                                                
18 A single household may lose both productive land and dwelling.  
19 Risk Assessment and Risk Management Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

10 
assurance that an O&M plan will be developed, implemented, and resourced to ensure long-term 
sustainability of the project facilities. The risks associated with procurement and corruption are low 
as all procurement activities are in advanced stage. ADB and AusAID will jointly monitor all 
procurement activities to ensure full compliance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines. Up-to-date 
information related to procurement, safeguard monitoring, and financial audit will be disclosed on 
ADB’s website as required by ADB’s Public Communications Policy, as well as on Cuu Long 
CIPM’s project website. The environmental, social, and resettlement related risks will be managed 
through joint ADB–AusAID monitoring of the environment management plan, SAP, resettlement 
plans, and income restoration programs during implementation. Unforeseen construction delays 
will be mitigated through provisions in the construction contracts. 
 
IV.  ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 
36.  The government and MOT have assured ADB that implementation of the project shall 
conform to all applicable ADB policies, including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in the project administration manual and loan documents. 
 
37.  The government and MOT have agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the project, 
which are set forth in the loan agreement. 
 
38.  MOT, through Cuu Long CIPM, will confirm to ADB in writing prior to issuing a site 
possession notice to a contractor for commencing work on a specific section of a contract that 
(i) payment of compensation has been fully disbursed to the affected people and rehabilitation 
measures are in place for that specific section in accordance with the project’s resettlement 
plans; (ii) affected people who were compensated for that specific section have vacated the site; 
and (iii) the specific section of the project is free from any encumbrances. 
 
39.  The ADB loan and the Government of Australia grant will not become effective until the 
Government of Viet Nam confirms in writing to ADB that adequate funding for component 3 has 
been secured on terms and conditions satisfactory to ADB. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
40.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve 
(i)  the loan of $410,000,000 to the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam for the Central 
Mekong Delta Region Connectivity Project, from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, 
with interest to be determined in accordance with ADB's London interbank offered 
rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility; for a term of 31 years, including a grace period 
of 6 years; and such other terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance 
with those set forth in the draft loan agreement presented to the Board; and 
(ii)  the  administration  by  ADB  of  a  grant  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of 
A$128,000,000 as provided in paragraph 14 of this report, to the Socialist Republic 
of  Viet  Nam for the  Central  Mekong  Delta  Region  Connectivity  Project, to  be 
provided by the Government of Australia. 
 
 
Takehiko Nakao 
President 
11 July 2013
